Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Attometer-Scale Thermal Fluctuations in Optical Coatings for Applications in Gravitational Wave Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the detection of Gravitational Waves (GW) by the Advanced Laser Interferometric Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) a new window to the Universe has been opened. These first detections only mark the beginning of a process to make LIGO more sensitive, increasing the detection rate with each step along the way. One of the most important open problems in LIGO noise reduction is related to the coatings of the mirrors used in the interferometer. Advances in precision optical measurement have made it possible to measure the thermal fluctuations of macroscopic materials. Thermal fluctuations in mechanical systems which occur at the atto-meter scale, and are known as "thermal noise", are a limiting noise source in gravitational wave detectors and in the best frequency references. This work will expand the scope of an ongoing experiment at MIT which was used to measure the thermal noise of Advanced LIGO mirrors. The new scope will include characterizing potential replacements for the coatings currently used in gravitational wave detectors.

The founding principle of the experiments supported by this award is that the thermal noise experienced by different spatial modes of a resonant cavity is easily separated from most technical noises, making a high signal to noise measurement possible in a tabletop experiment. These studies will test new materials used for ion-beam-sputtered (IBS) coatings, searching for new promising candidates to replace the coatings currently used by LIGO. Research in the area of coating thermal noise will allow us to extend the reach of gravitational wave detectors, make more precise clocks, and probe more deeply the quantum nature of opto-mechanical interactions. Since the proposed work will have a strong influence on the design of future gravitational wave detectors, its urgency cannot be overstated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the detection of Gravitational Waves (GW) by the Advanced Laser Interferometric Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) a new window to the Universe has been opened. These first detections only mark the beginning of a process to make LIGO more sensitive, increasing the detection rate with each step along the way. One of the most important open problems in LIGO noise reduction is related to the coatings of the mirrors used in the interferometer. Advances in precision optical measurement have made it possible to measure the thermal fluctuations of macroscopic materials. Thermal fluctuations in mechanical systems which occur at the atto-meter scale, and are known as "thermal noise", are a limiting noise source in gravitational wave detectors and in the best frequency references.

This project provided support for a graduate student at Massachusetts Institute of Technology to work on, and expand the scope of, an existing experiment that is used to directly measure coating thermal noise. We increased the throughput of the experiment and made the experiment available to measure coating samples from across the LIGO collaboration. We contributed direct measurements of coating thermal noise to most active areas of coating research, including amorphous oxides, nano-layers, buried “multi-material” coatings, and upper bounds for crystalline coatings. These measurements provide feedback that is critical to guide the direction of future coating research.

This project facilitated the beginning of an upgrade to the experiment that we expect to be complete by the end of the year. The upgraded experiment will be able to make 2-dimensional maps of coating thermal noise, and have improved sensitivity that will possibly allow for directly measuring the extremely low thermal noise of crystalline coatings.

Finding improved coatings is necessary to improve the sensitivity of gravitational-wave detectors. Improved detectors will have a broad impact across astrophysics, cosmology, and nuclear physics. They will allow measurements of the equation of state of neutron stars, distance ladder independent measurements of the hubble constant, more stringent tests of general relativity, insight into the source of gamma ray bursts, and enable multi-messenger astronomy and the study of the r-process in kilonovae.

Improved optical coatings will also improve other optical experiments that are currently coating thermal noise limited. This includes atomic clocks and experiments that probe opto-mechanical interactions. Some of the materials that we’ve explored will also be useful for telecommunications, especially the buried “multi-material” coatings.

The experimental results have been disseminated throughout the community via conferences, working group meetings, and public and private lab tours. This project has supported the training of a graduate student in both experimental optics and writing code for data analysis.
